options: Thank James and register the gift with the hospital
Politely leave as James is trying to bribe you
Politely explain that you are unable to discuss his father's condition with him unless Mr Smith consents to his information being shared
Decline the money and explain that you are unable to accept money in exchange for information
Listen to his concerns
Thank James and tell him to donate the money to a cancer charity instead
Thank James and take the cash. Tell him not to inform anyone of this and tell him everything about his father
Politely break the bad news to James
questions: You are a F2 working on the Gastro ward. You have been caring for Mr Smith, a 78-year-old with gastric cancer, for the last 3 weeks. His son James approaches you, asking to speak with you. You take him to the family room to discuss his concerns where he offers you £500 in cash to discuss his father's condition with him as his father is refusing to tell him what is wrong. What do you do?
notes:
The correct options are 3, 4 and 5. Patients have a right to confidentiality. It is Mr Smith's choice not to inform his family of his condition and you must respect this as a healthcare professional. However, this does not mean that you do not show compassion towards the son who may be feeling frustrated and at a loss. It is always good to listen to their concerns (option 1). You should decline the money and explain that you cannot give information in exchange for money (option 4). It is then important that you explain to the patient why you cannot share information- you need the patient's consent to do this (option 5).

All the other options break confidentiality, are unethical or accept a bribe. Telling James to donate the money to a charity may be putting undue pressure on him as he may now feel obliged to give the money.

The main theme in this question is confidentiality. For more information on confidentiality, see the GMC guidelines here: http://www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/ethicalguidance/confidentiality.asp

questions:
You are a junior doctor working in the Emergency Department. A colleague has recently returned from sick leave after suffering from lower back pain and sciatica. During your shift it is apparent that he is still in considerable pain; he is limping and very uncomfortable when sitting at the computer. At the end of your shift you witness him taking co-codamol from drug cupboard for himself.

Corrected. Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
It is not appropriate to self-prescribe or take NHS drugs without a prescription. Your colleague is evidently in pain, however the appropriate route is for him to see his own GP.

The best option is to speak to your colleague to clarify his actions.

The next best option is to inform a senior who can deal with the incident.

The GMC warns against writing prescriptions for friends and family so prescribing for your colleague would not be the best course of action.

options: Tell him to ring the medical director to make his complaint known
Put him in touch with the patient liaison and advice service (PALS)
Discuss his concerns with him at the nurses station there and then
Tell him you will see him in the patient's room with the ward matron to discuss his concerns
State that you do not deal with complaints and leave to look after your other patients
questions:
Mrs Smith is an 89 year-old palliative patient being cared for in a side room. Her son approaches you and states he would like to make a formal complaint due to the care Mrs Smith has received during her stay.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The best approach would be to discuss the relatives concerns, with the patient present if appropriate and another member of staff so you have a witness to the conversation. This would be better if it was the ward manager as he/she will have a lot of experience dealing with complaints.

PALS will be a useful contact for the patient's relative but not your first port of call. You want to maintain confidentiality so discussing the issues at the nurses station would be inappropriate.

Telling him to ring the medical director would waste his time and reflect badly on your team, given that you have not tried to address any of the issues yet. The medical director may get involved if the complaint gets taken further but not at this stage.

Not getting involved at all and walking away from the situation will only cause more trouble, and it is your duty to address any issues the patient/relative may have with the care provided by you and your team.

options: Take the patient at their word and take no further action
Inform him of the DVLA rules and your duty to inform the DVLA if he refuses to stop
Inform the DVLA immediately after telling the patient what you are going to do
Inform the DVLA anonymously to maintain the doctor-patient relationship
Confiscate his car keys during the consultation to prevent danger to the public
questions:
You are a GP registrar. Whilst parking at the surgery you notice a 34-year-old epileptic man also parking in the patient's car park. He has an appointment with you this morning. You know from previous consultations that his last fit was 7 months ago. During the consultation the patient denies driving.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
You have seen the patient drive yourself so it is wrong to simply ignore the situation. The best option is to inform him of the DVLA rules and your duty to notify the DVLA is he refuses to stop. Informing the DVLA immediately is not the best option as it does not allow the patient to rectify the situation themselves and may damage your long term relationship. It is always better to be honest and open with patients about your actions.

Confiscating the patient's keys is impractical and likely to lead to confrontation.

options: Inform him that it is illegal to aid anyone to commit euthanasia
Reassure him that you would be willing to use the 'double-effect' principle to hasten his death when he reaches the terminal phase
Give him details of the appropriate clinics in Switzerland
Discuss his fears about the terminal phase
Suggest he contacts the Motor Neuron Disease Association so that he can talk to people in a similar situation
questions:
You review a 60-year-old man who has motor neuron disease. He tells you he plans to go to Switzerland if he deteriorates as euthanasia is legal there.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This issue has become increasingly relevant in recent years with a number of UK patients travelling to the 'Dignitas' clinic in Switzerland. As the law currently stands it is illegal to aid anyone to commit suicide. The best response is to explore his fears about the terminal phase. This will allow you to discuss the progress made in palliative care. It may also be beneficial if he discusses his fears with people who have experience of similar scenarios. They may be able to provide reassurance.

If he remains committed to travel to Switzerland it is appropriate to inform him of the current legal situation. Giving him details of the appropriate clinics may be seen legally as aiding suicide.

The 'double-effect' principle means accepting the side-effects of appropriate pain relief, not deliberately hastening the life of a patient. Telling the patient you would be willing to effectively provide a form of euthanasia yourself (an illegal act in this country) is the worst option.

options: Speak to the locum consultant directly
Phone the local newspaper to help publicise the problem
Ask the nurses to put all the poorly or complex patients under a different consultant
Fill in a clinical incident form each time you disagree with a decision
Speak to the medical director
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor working on the medical admissions unit. You are currently working for a locum consultant with whom you have a good working relationship. However, both you and the nurses are concerned regarding the some of the management decisions and inappropriate discharges.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Concerns about the performance of a more senior colleague are difficult to handle. The most important thing is not to ignore the situation.

Speaking directly to the locum consultant should be the first step. He may take the attitude that given the concerns of both the medical and nursing staff it is appropriate to discuss his performance with his colleagues. It is, however, possible that he could become very defensive and try to stonewall you.

One of the advantages of speaking to the medical director is that he/she may already have concerns regarding their performance. Your comments may provide further 'evidence' on which action may be taken.

Filling a clinical incident form would hopefully trigger management to take action but it would take time before any action or decisions are made.

Asking the nurses to put all the poorly or complex patients under a different consultant may seem attractive as it may minimise harm but it does not tackle the underlying problem and puts other patients potentially at risk from an underperforming doctor.

Phoning the local newspaper is unprofessional, unlikely to result in a speedy resolution and will uniformly decrease local confidence in the department.

Take no further action as it is a nursing matter

questions:
You are a junior doctor on a medical ward. During the rotation, you become suspicious that it is common for one of the staff nurses to make up the observations on the observation chart. Your suspicions are confirmed when one day a patient's observations are recorded despite him spending the afternoon in the endoscopy suite.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
In situational judgement questions, it is nearly always best to speak to the person directly first, as this can clear up any misunderstanding. Clearly, if you are not satisfied with the explanation it is important to take the matter further.

As this problem involves a nurse the most appropriate person to speak to is the ward manager. Speaking to the consultant is a reasonable step as he/she should be aware if patient care could be affected.

Doing your own observations (we've all been there) avoids tackling the root of the problem, as does ignoring the problem completely.

options: Bleep the registrar again, ask fo his GMC number and threaten to make a complaint to his consultant if he does not accept the patient
Phone the medical consultant on-call and explain your concerns
Tell the patient to go to A&E herself with a written letter explaining the situation
Respect the opinion of the registrar and monitor the patient at home
Tell the patient to go to A&E herself but avoid writing a letter so as not to offend the admitting medical team
questions:
You are a GP registrar and review a 23-year-old who presented with headache, muscle aches and fever. On examination, she has a temperature of 38.3ºC and complains of some neck and back pains. You feel the most likely diagnosis is influenza but are concerned about the possibility of meningitis given the neck pain.

On phoning the hospital you speak to the medical registrar who interrupts you as you are trying to give the history, telling you: 'she's got flu, right? Why are you phoning me?'. On asking the registrar to accept the patient he refuses, tells you he's got to go as he is so busy and puts the phone down before you have a chance to give the full history.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Whilst the tempting thing is to have a row with the medical registrar this scenario looks for a more professional approach. Whilst it is true that the most likely cause for the patients' symptoms is influenza it is not unreasonable to want to exclude meningitis.

The best course of action is to try and reason with the registrar but if this fails the consultant on-call should be spoken to. They after all are in charge of the admitting medical team. As you have concerns about the patient it is important that they are seen in secondary care. It is, therefore, reasonable to send the patient to A&E for assessment, and more professional to give the patient a letter explaining the situation.

Taking a confrontational approach with the medical registrar is unlikely to result in a resolution of the situation and risks getting in the way of patient care.

It is clear from the scenario that the medical registrar has not made an appropriate assessment of the patient. As you have legitimate concerns it is, therefore, a very poor option to monitor the patient at home. This is the worst option as it threatens patient safety.

options: Offer to do extra sessions to help with the workload
Phone the primary care trust and inform them of your concerns
Help by pre-signing sick note forms
Do nothing
Tell the nurse clinician of your concerns and advise her that she may be breaching her own professional guidelines
questions:
You are a junior doctor on a GP rotation. You have been assigned to a surgery with two partners. One of the partners is on holiday leaving the other partner and a nurse clinician, who is not yet a prescriber. You notice he has pre-signed a full prescription pad to allow the nurse to issue prescriptions. You voice your concerns to the partner. He states that as the other partner is away they are very busy.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The pre-signing of prescriptions to allow another person who is not appropriately trained to prescribe is a serious matter and requires immediate action.

Making the nurse clinician aware of your concerns is the best first step as it shows you're trying to resolve the problem locally.

As the most senior person at the surgery is himself the problem, the scenario may require you to contact a higher body to help resolve the situation - this is the next best step.

Offering to do extra sessions is laudable but ignores the serious breach of professional standards by the partner as does ignoring the situation.

Helping to pre-sign sick note forms makes you complicit in the arrangement and is the worst option.

options: Alerting the Nursing and Midwifery Council of their member's contact
Ellie's safety and immediate management
Creating meticulous documentation of the events.
Checking on other patients on the ward and ensure their treatment has not been tampered with
Alerting the nurse in charge
questions:
You are an F2 on your paediatric rotation.

One of your patients is Ellie, a 5-year-old girl with a background of hydrocephalus whose discharge is repeatedly being delayed due to recurrent infections of her ventricular-peritoneal (VP) shunt. The team is puzzled as to what might be going on, as Ellie has had multiple surgeries to change the shunt and multiple courses of antibiotics.

As you walk into Ellie's room, a nurse startles, and makes a swift exit, throwing something in the sharps bin on her way out. You inspect the shunt line and it appears to have a hole in it.

Rank in order the importance of the following considerations in response to this situation (1= Most important; 5= Least important).
notes:
In this scenario, you are asked to decide on the most appropriate way to raise a concern about a patient's safety as a junior doctor.

Making sure the patient is safe Ellie's safety and immediate management should always be your first consideration.

Next, the nurse in charge should be informed alerting the nurse in charge, as she will be able to act quickly to ensure the nurse stops working, pending clarification of the matter. This is to ensure other patients' safety as well.

The safety of other patients is your next priority checking on other patients on the ward and ensuring their treatment has not been tampered with should be done without delay.

Creating meticulous documentation of the events is important, should not be the priority, as patient safety always comes first.

It will not be your role to inform the NMC alerting the Nursing and Midwifery Council of their member's contact. Although the NMC should and will be alerted eventually, they cannot help with the immediate situation, and creating meticulous documentation is more important in the first instance.

title: GMC: Raising and acting on concerns about patient safety
body:
The GMC take a firm line on patient safety, in that you must take action if you think patient safety, dignity or comfort is being compromised. This is not always easy, particularly as a student or junior doctor- which is why it is important to be aware of the guidance.

Broad Principles

All doctors have the duty to raise concerns if they believe that patient safety or care is being compromised. This can include when medical students witness poor practice on placement, or family members raise concerns. They must also encourage and support a culture in which staff can raise concerns openly and safely.

Concerns may relate to:
  • The practice of colleagues,
  • The systems in place,
  • Policies and procedures within organisations.

You may be reluctant to report a concern for a number of reasons, particularly if you have not needed to raise concerns in the past. For example:
  • You fear that nothing will be done,
  • You fear that raising your concern may cause problems for colleagues,
  • It could have a negative effect on working relationships or career,
  • It could result in a complaint about you.

While it is natural to have these concerns, keep the following in mind:
  • You have a duty to put patients' interests first and act to protect them. This should override personal and professional loyalties.
  • The law provides legal protection. This is against victimisation or dismissal for individuals who reveal information to raise genuine concerns and expose malpractice in the workplace.
  • You do not need to wait for proof. You can justify raising a concern if you do so honestly, on the basis of reasonable belief and through appropriate channels.

For example, you may believe that a member of staff is intentionally avoiding guidance on hand-washing. When reporting this, you must be clear, honest and objective about the reason for your concern. You should also keep a record of any steps that you have taken to deal with it.

Who to report to

Wherever possible, you should first raise your concern with your manager or an appropriate officer, such as:
  • The consultant in charge of the team,
  • The clinical or medical director,
  • A practice partner.

NB: If your concern is about a partner, it may be appropriate to raise it outside the practice.

If you are a doctor in training, it may be appropriate to raise your concerns with a named person in the deanery. One example could be where a senior clinician has been reported by a number of patients for improper practice, and you would like to seek further advise on what action to take.

You should contact a regulatory body, such as the General Medical Council, in the following circumstances.
  • If you cannot raise the issue with the responsible person or body locally because you believe them to be part of the problem.
  • If you have raised your concern through local channels but are not satisfied that the responsible person or body has taken adequate action.
  • If there is an immediate serious risk to patients, and a regulator or other external body has responsibility to act or intervene.

It is not common to raise concerns publicly, as they can usually be dealt with discretely by the appropriate team. However, you can consider making your concerns public if you:
  • Have done all you can to deal with any concern by raising it within the organisation in which you work or which you have contract with, or with the appropriate external body, and
  • Have good reason to believe that patients are still at risk of harm,
  • Do not breach patient confidentiality.

Acting on Concerns

As a medical student or recently qualified doctor, you may not need to do more than report concerns. However, concerns about patient safety can also come from a number of sources, such as:
  • Patients' complaints,
  • Colleagues' concerns,
  • Critical incident reports,
  • Clinical audit.

If you receive this information, you have a responsibility to act on it promptly and professionally. You can do this by putting the matter right (if possible), investigating and dealing with it locally, or referring serious or repeated incidents to senior management.

If you have a management role or responsibility, you must make sure that:
  • There are systems and policies in place to allow concerns and investigated promptly and fully,
  • You do not try to prevent employees or former employees raising concerns about patient safety,
  • Clinical staff understand their duty to be open and honest about incidents or complaints with both patients and managers,
  • Staff who raise a concern are protected from unfair criticism or action, including any detriment or dismissal.

If you are responsible for investigating incidents or complaints, you must:
  • Tell the person what action has been taken to prevent a recurrence of the problem,
  • Outline the process if they are still not satisfied with the response,
  • Ensure that any investigations or resulting actions are carried out in a way which is consistent with the law.
